alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for congestion charges
overview: Tax and reporting rules for employers covering the cost of congestion charges
title: Expenses and benefits: congestion charges

table.body:
As an employer covering the costs of congestion charges for your employees, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations.

Different rules apply depending on whether the employee used a company vehicle or their own car, and whether they were travelling on business or not.

##Business travel

Travelling on business means that the employee either travels as part of their job (eg for meetings) or needs to go to a temporary workplace. Everything else is counted as private travel.


*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You don’t have to report or pay anything to HMRC if the employee is either:

- driving in a company vehicle 
- using their own vehicle for business travel and earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year


*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: What's exempt

table.body:
If congestion charges aren't [exempt](/expenses-and-benefits-congestion-charges/whats-exempt "What is exempt"), you must report them to HMRC, and may have to deduct and pay tax and National Insurance on them.

The value of the benefit to use is the amount you pay in congestion charges.

^You can [apply for a dispensation](/apply-for-a-dispensation "apply for a dispensation"), which means you won’t have to include congestion charges on your end-of-year reports.^

##If the employee is using their own vehicle to travel on business

Who gets the benefit | What to do | What to deduct or pay
- | - | - 
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of £8,500 or more a year| Report on form P11D, section N | Nothing
Directors | Report on form P11D, section N | Nothing

##If you pay congestion charges directly for an employee's private travel

Who gets the benefit | What to do | What to deduct or pay
- | - | -
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year | Report on form P9D, section A(2) | Deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) through payroll
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate")  of £8,500 or more a year | Report on form P11D, section N | Deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) through payroll
Directors | Report on form P11D, section N | Deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) through payroll

##If you reimburse congestion charges for an employee's private travel

This counts as earnings, so you'll need to:

* add the value of the benefit to your employee's other earnings
* deduct and pay Class 1 National Insurance and PAYE tax through payroll.  

*[PAYE]:Pay as you earn
*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
